message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are characteristic for paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT) and the absence of P waves in ECG recordings suggest AV nodal reentry tachycardia (AVNRT). AVNRT is caused by slow and fast pathways in the AV node. Pre-excitation of the ventricles would show a delta wave in ECG recordings. Fibrosis of the sinoatrial node and surrounding myocardium is associated with sinus node dysfunction. Mutations in genes that code for myocyte ion channels are associated with inherited channelopathies.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the ECG recordings suggest AV node with slow and fast pathway, also known as atrioventricular nodal reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT), as the most likely underlying cause. Pre-excitation of the ventricles can cause a similar presentation but would show a shortened PR interval on the ECG. Fibrosis of the sinoatrial node and mutations in genes that code for myocyte ion channels would not typically present with episodes of tachycardia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a diagnosis of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). The absence of P waves on ECG recordings during episodes of tachycardia is suggestive of AV nodal reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT), which is caused by the presence of slow and fast pathways in the AV node. The other options are less likely causes of PSVT.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms of chest pain, racing pulse, dizziness, and difficulty breathing suggest episodes of supraventricular tachycardia (SVT). The absence of P waves on ECG recordings during episodes suggests paroxysmal SVT. Among the options, AV node with slow and fast pathway is the most likely underlying cause of this condition, as it is the most common form of paroxysmal SVT. Pre-excitation of ventricles is associated with Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome, which would show delta waves on ECG. Fibrosis of the sinoatrial node and surrounding myocardium is associated with sick sinus syndrome, which would present with bradycardia or sinus pauses, not tachycardia. Mutations in genes that code for myocyte ion channels are associated with long QT syndrome, which presents with arrhythmias triggered by exercise or emotional stress, but not necessarily with SVT.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms are consistent with paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT), and the absence of P waves on ECG suggests an atrioventricular nodal reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT) or atrioventricular reentrant tachycardia (AVRT). AVNRT occurs due to two distinct pathways in the AV node, a slow and a fast pathway, resulting in re-entry tachycardia. Therefore, the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition is AV node with slow and fast pathway.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia, which can be caused by AV node with slow and fast pathway. Pre-excitation of the ventricles can cause Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome, which is not consistent with the absence of P waves on ECG recordings. Fibrosis of the sinoatrial node and surrounding myocardium could cause sick sinus syndrome, which is not consistent with the regular RR-interval on ECG recordings. Mutations in genes that code for myocyte ion channels could cause long QT syndrome, which is not consistent with the absence of P waves on ECG recordings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of chest pain, racing pulse, dizziness, and difficulty breathing, along with the absence of P waves on ECG suggest the condition is paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). Among the options, AV node with slow and fast pathway is the most likely underlying cause of PSVT. Pre-excitation of the ventricles has a characteristic delta wave on ECG, which is not mentioned in the case. Fibrosis of the sinoatrial node and surrounding myocardium would cause sinus node dysfunction, not PSVT. Mutations in genes that code for myocyte ion channels are associated with long QT syndrome or Brugada syndrome, which are not consistent with the symptoms described in the case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms indicate paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT), and the absence of P waves on ECG during tachycardia suggests that the AV node is involved. Option A describes AV node with slow and fast pathway, which is a common mechanism for PSVT. Option B describes Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome, which is another cause of PSVT but is characterized by a short PR interval and delta waves on ECG. Option C describes sick sinus syndrome, which is a cause of abnormal sinus rhythms but does not typically cause PSVT. Option D describes channelopathies that can cause arrhythmias but is less likely to be the cause in this patient with no personal or family history of serious illness.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and Holter monitoring show that the patient has supraventricular tachycardia (SVT). The absence of P waves on ECG recordings suggests that SVT is caused by an AV node with slow and fast pathway. Pre-excitation of the ventricles would cause a shortened QRS duration, not a prolonged one. Fibrosis of the sinoatrial node and surrounding myocardium would result in sinoatrial node dysfunction, not SVT. Mutations in genes that code for myocyte ion channels may cause various arrhythmias but do not specifically indicate SVT.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including chest pain, racing pulse, dizziness, and difficulty breathing suggest a diagnosis of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). The absence of P waves on the ECG recordings during episodes of tachycardia suggests that the condition is caused by an abnormal AV node with slow and fast pathways. This can result in reentry of electrical impulses, leading to PSVT. Pre-excitation of the ventricles, fibrosis of the sinoatrial node and surrounding myocardium, and mutations in genes that code for myocyte ion channels can also cause arrhythmias but are less likely to be the cause of the patient's condition based on her symptoms and ECG findings.
